title: USS Arapaho (ATF-68)
text:
USS "Arapaho" (AT-68/ATF-68) was a <a href="fleet%20ocean%20tug">fleet ocean tug</a> which served the <a href="U.S.%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> with her towing services. She was assigned initially to support the <a href="U.S.%20Atlantic%20Fleet">U.S. Atlantic Fleet</a>, and was eventually assigned to support Allied forces in the war zones of the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, resulting in her crew returning home after the war with four <a href="battle%20stars">battle stars</a> to their credit.
US Navy career.
The second ship to be so named by the Navy, "Arapaho" (AT-68) was laid down on 8 November 1941 at <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>, by the Charleston Shipbuilding & Dry-dock Company; launched on 22 June 1942; sponsored by Mrs. Alice Posey Hatcher; and commissioned on 20 January 1943, Lt. E. H. Wootan in command.
World War II service.
East coast operations.
The tug conducted her <a href="Shakedown%20%28testing%29">shakedown</a> training in the vicinity of <a href="Key%20West%2C%20Florida">Key West, Florida</a>, and returned to <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, to prepare for a <a href="transatlantic%20crossing">transatlantic</a> voyage. On 19 March, she sailed for <a href="Casablanca">Casablanca</a>, Morocco. There, she took the <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>-damaged attack cargo ship <a href="USS%20Almaack%20%28AKA-10%29">"Almaack" (AKA-10)</a> in tow for the voyage back to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. She and her charge arrived back in <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, on 20 May.
In mid-June, the tug moved south to search the <a href="Florida%20Strait">Florida Strait</a> for the <a href="submarine">submarine</a> <a href="USS%20R-12%20%28SS-89%29">"R-12 (SS-89")</a>, which had sunk as a result of battery explosions. After fruitlessly seeking this ship from 18 to 23 June, "Arapaho" set sail on 25 June—apparently from <a href="Key%20West%2C%20Florida">Key West, Florida</a>—with a barge in tow on her way to <a href="Panama">Panama</a>. She left the barge in the <a href="Panama%20Canal%20Zone">Panama Canal Zone</a> and continued her voyage to <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>, where she arrived on 15 July.
Pacific Ocean operations.
For the next three months, the tug conducted towing and salvage operations, first along the <a href="U.S.%20West%20Coast">U.S. West Coast</a> and then, from early in September, out of <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>. On 16 October, "Arapaho" departed <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> with two supply lighters in tow, bound for the <a href="Ellice%20Islands">Ellice Islands</a>. She reached <a href="Funafuti">Funafuti</a> on 30 October and began heavy towing operations between the <a href="Ellice%20Islands">Ellice</a> and <a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilbert Islands</a>. For a time, she served as an <a href="antisubmarine">antisubmarine</a> guard ship at recently captured <a href="Tarawa">Tarawa</a> Atoll.
On 4 December, "Arapaho" embarked 12 civilians who had been liberated from a <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japanese</a> <a href="internment%20camp">internment camp</a> on <a href="Makin%20Island%2C%20Makin">Makin</a> and set sail—via <a href="Funafuti">Funafuti</a>—for <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>. From Funafuti, the tug steamed in company with aircraft carrier <a href="USS%20Independence%20%28CVL-22%29">"Independence" (CVL-22)</a>, severely damaged in the <a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilbert Islands</a> operation by an <a href="aerial%20torpedo">aerial torpedo</a>. The ships arrived at Pearl Harbor on 18 December.
"Arapaho" underwent repairs until near the end of the first week in January 1944. On 6 January, she headed back to the <a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilberts</a>. Over the next five months, the tug was based successively at <a href="Tarawa">Tarawa</a> and <a href="Majuro">Majuro</a>, though she made numerous tows to other islands in the Gilbert, Marshall, and Ellice groups. By 13 June, she had moved her base of operations to <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a> where she engaged in harbor duty and salvage work. On 3 July, "Arapaho" set a course for Pearl Harbor, which she reached on the 9th to begin a month of repairs. She returned to Eniwetok on 26 August and, except for a round-trip voyage to <a href="Guam">Guam</a>, operated there until the second week in October.
Ulithi operations.
At that time, she put to sea towing auxiliary repair dock "ARD-15" and covered lighter (self-propelled) "YF-786" to Ulithi, <a href="Service%20Squadron">Service Squadron</a> (ServRon) 10's new advanced base, and, following her arrival at that <a href="atoll">atoll</a>, worked in and out of its <a href="lagoon">lagoon</a> engaged in harbor and salvage duties.
Between 4 and 10 November, she assisted <a href="USS%20Zuni%20%28ATF-95%29">"Zuni" (ATF-95)</a> in towing <a href="USS%20Reno%20%28CL-96%29">"Reno" (CL-96)</a> into <a href="Ulithi">Ulithi</a>. The <a href="light%20cruiser">light cruiser</a> had been torpedoed by a Japanese <a href="submarine">submarine</a> off the <a href="San%20Bernardino%20Strait">San Bernardino Strait</a> on the 3d. In December, the tug towed <a href="USS%20Houston%20%28CL-81%29">"Houston" (CL-81)</a> from <a href="Ulithi">Ulithi</a> to <a href="Manus%20Island">Manus</a> in the <a href="Admiralty%20Islands">Admiralty Islands</a>. From there, she towed fuel barge "YO-186" to <a href="Kossol%20Passage">Kossol Passage</a> in the <a href="Palau%20Islands">Palau Islands</a>. After towing <a href="USS%20LST-278">"LST-278"</a> to <a href="Guam">Guam</a> in January 1945, "Arapaho" returned to Ulithi on the 23d and began a major overhaul of her main propulsion plant. The ship completed repairs and returned to active duty on 18 March.
Okinawa operations.
She operated out of Ulithi until mid-June when she moved to Guam. From there, the tug headed for <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a> on 5 July with auxiliary repair dock "ARD-26" in tow. "Arapaho" and the auxiliary repair dock arrived in <a href="Kerama%20Retto">Kerama Retto</a> 10 days later. The tug remained at <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a> until after the end of hostilities in mid-August. Late that month, she voyaged back to Guam to pick up "ARD-21" for tow to Okinawa. She returned to Kerama Retto with her charge on 7 September and resumed local towing duty.
End-of-war decommissioning.
That assignment continued until 9 November 1945 when she began the long journey back to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. She stopped at <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> for a few days early in December and arrived in <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20Los%20Angeles">San Pedro, Los Angeles</a>, on 27th. "Arapaho" remained at San Pedro assigned to the inactive fleet awaiting inactivation overhaul for a little more than a year. On 8 and 9 January 1947, she was towed to <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>, where she was decommissioned on 15 January 1947. She remained with the <a href="Pacific%20Reserve%20Fleet">Pacific Reserve Fleet</a> until July 1961. On 1 July 1961, her name was struck from the <a href="Navy%20list">Navy list</a>.
Honors and awards.
"Arapaho" (ATF-68) earned four <a href="battle%20stars">battle stars</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Argentine Navy career.
On 10 July 1961, she was transferred to the <a href="Argentine%20Navy">Argentine Navy</a>, which commissioned her that same day as ARA "Comandante General Zapiola". The tug remained active with the Argentine Navy until 10 January 1976 when she ran aground on an <a href="Antarctica">Antarctic</a> reef and was declared a total loss. Her crew was rescued by the Chilean patrol boat "Piloto Pardo".
